text: James, a slave of God and of the Lord Jesus Christ, to the twelve tribes in the dispersion. Greetings!
speaker: Narrator

text: Consider it all joy, my brothers, whenever you encounter various trials,
speaker: Narrator

text: because you know that the testing of your faith produces endurance.
speaker: Narrator

text: And let endurance have its perfect effect, so that you may be mature and complete, lacking in nothing.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now if any of you lacks wisdom, let him ask for it from God, who gives to all without reservation and not reproaching, and it will be given to him.
speaker: Narrator

text: But let him ask for it in faith, without any doubting, for the one who doubts is like the surf of the sea, driven by the wind and tossed about.
speaker: Narrator

text: For that person must not suppose that he will receive anything from the Lord;
speaker: Narrator

text: he is a double-minded man, unstable in all his ways.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now let the brother of humble circumstances boast in his high position,
speaker: Narrator

text: but the rich person in his humiliation, because he will pass away like a flower of the grass.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the sun rises with its burning heat and dries up the grass, and its flower falls off, and the beauty of its appearance is lost. So also the rich person in his pursuits will wither away.
speaker: Narrator

text: Blessed is the person who endures testing, because when he is approved he will receive the crown of life that he has promised to those who love him.
speaker: Narrator

text: No one who is being tempted should say, “I am being tempted by God,” for God cannot be tempted by evil, and he himself tempts no one.
speaker: Narrator

text: But each one is tempted when he is dragged away and enticed by his own desires.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then desire, after it has conceived, gives birth to sin, and sin, when it is brought to completion, gives birth to death.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do not be deceived, my dear brothers.
speaker: Narrator

text: Every good gift and every perfect gift is from above, coming down from the Father of lights, with whom there is no variation or shadow of change.
speaker: Narrator

text: By his will he gave birth to us through the message of truth, so that we should be a kind of first fruits of his creatures.
speaker: Narrator

text: Understand this, my dear brothers: every person must be quick to hear, slow to speak, slow to anger,
speaker: Narrator

text: for human anger does not accomplish the righteousness of God.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore, putting aside all moral uncleanness and wicked excess, welcome with humility the implanted message which is able to save your souls.
speaker: Narrator

text: But be doers of the message and not hearers only, deceiving yourselves,
speaker: Narrator

text: because if anyone is a hearer of the message and not a doer, this one is like someone staring at his own face in a mirror,
speaker: Narrator

text: for he looks at himself and goes away and immediately forgets what sort of person he was.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the one who looks into the perfect law of liberty and continues to do it, not being a forgetful hearer but a doer who acts, this one will be blessed in what he does.
speaker: Narrator

text: If anyone thinks he is religious, although he does not bridle his tongue but deceives his heart, this person’s religion is worthless.
speaker: Narrator

text: Pure and undefiled religion in the sight of our God and Father is this: to look after orphans and widows in their affliction, and to keep oneself unstained by the world.
speaker: Narrator

text: My brothers, do not hold your faith in our glorious Lord Jesus Christ with partiality.
speaker: Narrator

text: For if someone enters into your assembly in fine clothing with a gold ring on his finger, and a poor person in filthy clothing also enters,
speaker: Narrator

text: and you look favorably on the one wearing the fine clothing and you say, “Be seated here in a good place,” and to the poor person you say, “You stand or be seated there by my footstool,”
speaker: Narrator

text: have you not made distinctions among yourselves and become judges with evil thoughts?
speaker: Narrator

text: Listen, my dear brothers! Did not God choose the poor of the world to be rich in faith, and heirs of the kingdom that he has promised to those who love him?
speaker: Narrator

text: But you have dishonored the poor! Are not the rich exploiting you and they themselves dragging you into the courts?
speaker: Narrator

text: Do they themselves not blaspheme the good name of the one to whom you belong?
speaker: Narrator

text: However, if you carry out the royal law according to the scripture, “You shall love your neighbor as yourself,” you are doing well.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if you show partiality, you commit sin, and thus are convicted by the law as transgressors.
speaker: Narrator

text: For whoever keeps the whole law but stumbles in one point only has become guilty of all of it.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the one who said “Do not commit adultery” also said “Do not murder.” Now if you do not commit adultery but you do murder, you have become a transgressor of the law.
speaker: Narrator

text: Thus speak and thus act as those who are going to be judged by the law of liberty.
speaker: Narrator

text: For judgment is merciless to the one who has not practiced mercy. Mercy triumphs over judgment.
speaker: Narrator

text: What is the benefit, my brothers, if someone says that he has faith but does not have works? That faith is not able to save him, is it?
speaker: Narrator

text: If a brother or a sister is poorly clothed and lacking food for the day,
speaker: Narrator

text: and one of you should say to them, “Go in peace, keep warm and eat well,” but does not give them what is necessary for the body, what is the benefit?
speaker: Narrator

text: Thus also faith, if it does not have works, is dead by itself.
speaker: Narrator

text: But someone will say, “You have faith and I have works.” Show me your faith apart from your works, and I will show you my faith by my works.
speaker: Narrator

text: You believe that God is one; you do well. Even the demons believe, and shudder!
speaker: Narrator

text: But do you want to know, O foolish person, that faith apart from works is useless?
speaker: Narrator

text: Was not Abraham our father justified by works when he offered up his son Isaac on the altar?
speaker: Narrator

text: You see that faith was working together with his works, and by the works the faith was perfected.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the scripture was fulfilled that says, “And Abraham believed God, and it was credited to him for righteousness,” and he was called God’s friend.
speaker: Narrator

text: You see that a person is justified by works and not by faith alone.
speaker: Narrator

text: And likewise was not Rahab the prostitute also justified by works when she welcomed the messengers and sent them out by a different route?
speaker: Narrator

text: For just as the body without the spirit is dead, so also faith without works is dead.
speaker: Narrator

text: Not many should become teachers, my brothers, because you know that we will receive a greater judgment.
speaker: Narrator

text: For we all stumble in many ways. If anyone does not stumble in what he says, he is a perfect individual, able to hold in check his whole body also.
speaker: Narrator

text: And if we put bits in the mouths of horses so that they obey us, we also guide their whole bodies.
speaker: Narrator

text: Behold also ships: although they are so large and are driven by strong winds, they are guided by a very small rudder wherever the inclination of the pilot wishes.
speaker: Narrator

text: So also the tongue is a small member of the body and boasts great things. Behold how small a fire sets ablaze how great a forest!
speaker: Narrator

text: And the tongue is a fire! The world of unrighteousness, the tongue, is set among our members, defiling the whole body and setting on fire the course of human existence, being set on fire by hell.
speaker: Narrator

text: For every species of animals and birds, of reptiles and sea creatures, is being tamed and has been tamed by the human species,
speaker: Narrator

text: but no human being is able to tame the tongue. It is a restless evil, full of deadly poison.
speaker: Narrator

text: With it we bless the Lord and Father, and with it we curse people who are made in the likeness of God.
speaker: Narrator

text: From the same mouth come blessing and cursing. My brothers, these things ought not to be so!
speaker: Narrator

text: A spring does not pour forth from the same opening fresh and bitter water, does it?
speaker: Narrator

text: A fig tree is not able, my brothers, to produce olives, or a grapevine figs. Neither can a saltwater spring produce fresh water.
speaker: Narrator

text: Who is wise and understanding among you? Let him show by his good behavior his works, with the humility of wisdom.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if you have bitter jealousy and selfish ambition in your hearts, do not boast and tell lies against the truth.
speaker: Narrator

text: This is not the wisdom that comes down from above, but is earthly, unspiritual, demonic.
speaker: Narrator

text: For where there is jealousy and selfish ambition, there is disorder and every evil practice.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the wisdom from above is first pure, then peaceful, gentle, obedient, full of mercy and good fruits, nonjudgmental, without hypocrisy,
speaker: Narrator

text: And the fruit of righteousness is sown in peace among those who make peace.
speaker: Narrator

text: From where are conflicts and from where are quarrels among you? Is it not from this, from your pleasures that wage war among your members?
speaker: Narrator

text: You desire and do not have; you murder and are filled with envy, and are not able to obtain; you fight and quarrel. You do not have because you do not ask.
speaker: Narrator

text: You ask and do not receive, because you ask with wrong motives, in order that you may spend it on your pleasures.
speaker: Narrator

text: Adulterous people! Do you not know that friendship with the world is enmity with God? Therefore whoever wants to be a friend of the world makes himself an enemy of God.
speaker: Narrator

text: Or do you think that in vain the scripture says, “The spirit which he caused to dwell in us desires jealously”?
speaker: Narrator

text:
But he gives greater grace. Therefore it says,
“God opposes the proud,
    but gives grace to the humble.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore subject yourselves to God. But resist the devil, and he will flee from you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Draw near to God, and he will draw near to you. Cleanse your hands, you sinners, and purify your hearts, you double-minded!
speaker: Narrator

text: Lament and mourn and weep! Let your laughter be turned to mourning, and your joy to gloominess.
speaker: Narrator

text: Humble yourselves before the Lord, and he will exalt you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do not speak evil of one another, brothers. The one who speaks evil of a brother or judges his brother speaks evil of the law and judges the law. But if you judge the law, you are not a doer of the law but a judge of the law.
speaker: Narrator

text: There is one lawgiver and judge who is able to save and to destroy. But who are you to judge your neighbor?
speaker: Narrator

text: Come now, you who say, “Today or tomorrow we will travel to such and such a city and spend a year there, and carry on business and make a profit,”
speaker: Narrator

text: you who do not know what will happen tomorrow, what your life will be like. For you are a smoky vapor that appears for a short time and then disappears.
speaker: Narrator

text: Instead you should say, “If the Lord wills, we will live and do this or that.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But now you boast in your arrogance. All such boasting is evil.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore, to the one who knows to do good and does not do it, to him it is sin.
speaker: Narrator

text: Come now, you rich people, weep and cry aloud over the miseries that are coming upon you!
speaker: Narrator

text: Your wealth has rotted, and your clothing has become moth-eaten.
speaker: Narrator

text: Your gold and silver have become corroded, and their corrosion will be a witness against you, and it will consume your flesh like fire. You have stored up treasure in the last days.
speaker: Narrator

text: Behold, the wages that were held back by you from the workers who reap your fields cry out, and the cries of the reapers have come to the ears of the Lord of hosts.
speaker: Narrator

text: You have lived self-indulgently on the earth and have lived luxuriously. You have fattened your hearts in the day of slaughter.
speaker: Narrator

text: You have condemned, you have murdered the righteous person; he does not resist you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore be patient, brothers, until the coming of the Lord. Behold, the farmer waits for the precious fruit of the soil, being patient concerning it until it receives the early and late rains.
speaker: Narrator

text: You also be patient. Strengthen your hearts, because the coming of the Lord is near.
speaker: Narrator

text: Brothers, do not complain against one another, in order that you may not be judged. Behold, the judge stands before the doors!
speaker: Narrator

text: Brothers, take as an example of perseverance and endurance the prophets who spoke in the name of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Behold, we consider blessed those who have endured. You have heard about the patient endurance of Job, and you saw the outcome from the Lord, that the Lord is compassionate and merciful.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now above all, my brothers, do not swear either by heaven or by earth or by any other oath, but let your yes be yes and your no, no, in order that you may not fall under judgment.
speaker: Narrator

text: Is anyone among you suffering misfortune? He should pray. Is anyone cheerful? He should sing praise.
speaker: Narrator

text: Is anyone among you sick? He should summon the elders of the church and they should pray over him, anointing him with olive oil in the name of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the prayer of faith will save the one who is sick, and the Lord will raise him up, and if he has committed sins he will be forgiven.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore confess your sins to one another, and pray for one another, so that you may be healed. The effective prayer of a righteous person accomplishes much.
speaker: Narrator

text: Elijah was a human being with the same nature as us, and he prayed fervently for it not to rain, and it did not rain on the land for three years and six months.
speaker: Narrator

text: And he prayed again, and the sky gave rain and the earth produced its fruit.
speaker: Narrator

text: My brothers, if anyone among you should wander away from the truth and someone turns him back,
speaker: Narrator

text: he should know that the one who turns a sinner back from the error of his way will save that person’s soul from death, and will cover over a great number of sins.
speaker: Narrator
